oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Kraftstoffverbrauch und Reduktionspotenziale
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Moitzi, Dr. Gerhard
Boxberger, Univ. Prof. Dr. Josef
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Air and water emissions
Soil tillage
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Although Organic Farming has lower CO2-Emission than Conventional Farming, there is a further need to reduce the direct energy input especially in form of fossil fuel consumption. Burning of one liter fossil diesel in an engine emits 2.62 kg fossil CO2. Some selected measurements for increasing the fuel efficiency are presented and discussed. Soil tillage with mould plough is an energy intensive process. Alternative soil tillage systems without plough should be adapted for specific requirements in Organic Farming. The usage of bio fuel (pure plant oil in adapted engines) in Organic Farming should be more promoted
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Moitzi, Dr. Gerhard and Boxberger, Univ. Prof. Dr. Josef (2009) Kraftstoffverbrauch und Reduktionspotenziale. Paper at: 10. Wissenschaftstagung Ökologischer Landbau, Zürich, 11.-13. Februar 2009.
